content.description: Sit start on a slopey arête with your left foot on a decent foothold at knee height. Traverse right, turn the corner, move up the arête all the way to the end, and top out.
content.location: Locate the far left end of the boulder. There is a small pile of wood there. This problem starts about 5 feet left of the corner.

content.description: Sit start the overhanging face with your left hand on a higher, flat crimp and your right hand on a low, circular crimp. Move straight up to the arête, and traverse all the way right to top out.
content.location: This problem is located on the far left end of the boulder.

content.description: Sit start as for the problem Shamen, but after a few crimps, move right to the curved flake, match, then to the far arête, and top out.
content.location: It is on the far left end of the boulder.

content.description: Low sit start on the steep arête with your left hand on a pretty low micro-crimp and your right hand on a higher, flat, black hold about a foot beneath the arete. Move up to the arête proper without dabbing on the ramp, match, use some serious core and compression to ascend the arête and top out. Although the upper arête is sharp, this rig still gets 4 stars based upon its geometry and movement. The grade given is for the low start described.
content.location: This ascends the dead obvious, steep, left-leaning arête located about a foot left of the split in the boulder.

content.description: Sit start low on the long ramp, and move into the dead obvious bulge just right of the split in the boulder. Move up on cool holds, and top out.
content.location: This problem starts on the low, rising ramp just right of the split in the boulder.

content.description: Sit start on the low, rising ramp as for the problem Manitou, but after a few moves, move right to match on a cool crimp bar and then to a harder topout.
content.location: Do the same start as for the problem Manitou.

content.description: Sit start on thin crimps under a steep roof. Move up on a series of flat jugs, and top out. It is easier if you use either arete. The straight-on version is V2+.
content.location: This is the dead obvious steep roof with BOP spray painted on it.

content.description: Algonquin Boulder is a decent, 12 foot boulder split into two halves with about a half dozen problems. The harder problems are on the back left side of the split while the easier ones are found on the back right side of the split. The problems are sorted as they appear upon approach. This boulder is cool for a solo outing as it is not too tall. If you are local, it might be worthy of a visit.
